Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment (complex, layered situation)

exchanges.user:
So been thinking about what to talk about. Work's been a mess like always, but that's not even the main thing right now.

I've got this friend, Marcus, we've known each other since college. Really close, or at least I thought we were. Anyway we were supposed to grab drinks last week and he just... didn't show up. Didn't text, nothing. I called him the next day trying to figure out what happened and he was like "oh man sorry I totally forgot" and then made some excuse about his girlfriend. 

Which like, ok people forget things. But then I started thinking about it and I realized I can't actually remember the last time we hung out in person. It's been months maybe? And now I'm kind of spiraling about whether he actually wants to be friends anymore or if I'm just being paranoid. Like maybe I'm the problem, maybe I'm too much or something. I don't know.

The thing is I get anxious about this stuff. Like worried people are judging me or that I'm gonna say something wrong and they'll think I'm weird. So usually I just... don't reach out as much. Which probably makes it worse. It's like I'm waiting for them to make the effort and they're probably waiting for me and then months go by and it feels too awkward to just call.

Anyway. How do I fix this?
exchanges.assistant:
**The Marcus situation:** It makes sense you're feeling thrown off by this—flaking without a word hits differently when it's someone you've been close with for years. And noticing that months-long gap must've landed hard. One thing I'm curious about: when you say "maybe I'm the problem, maybe I'm too much"—where does that thought come from? Is that a familiar fear that shows up in other friendships, or is this specific to Marcus?

**The pattern you're describing:** You named something really important here: you hold back because you're worried about judgment, they maybe do the same, and then the distance just grows. That loop is painful because you're protecting yourself from rejection, but the protection itself creates the very distance you're afraid of. Does that resonate? Like the anxiety is trying to keep you safe but might actually be working against what you want?

**What might help:** One option is to test what happens if you break the pattern—not with a big vulnerable conversation (that can feel too high-stakes), but something small. Like: "Hey, been too long. Want to grab coffee next week?" If he says yes and shows up, you've got data that he's still interested. If he flakes again or makes excuses, that's also data—maybe painful, but clarifying. Either way, you'd know more than you do now spiraling in uncertainty. Worth trying?

And separately: you mentioned this anxiety about being judged or saying something wrong shows up with other people too. How much does that worry run your social life in general? Like is it just friendships, or does it show up at work, family stuff, meeting new people?

exchanges.user:
So I did the thing. Called Marcus yesterday, just kept it casual like you said. He was actually... nice about it? Like seemed genuinely happy to hear from me. We set something up for next weekend, drinks at that place we used to go to.

But now I'm doing the thing where I'm like overthinking it already. Like what if I show up and it's weird and we don't have anything to talk about? What if I've changed or he's changed and we don't click anymore? I know that's probably me spiraling but it's hard to turn off.

Also been thinking about what you asked about the anxiety showing up in other places. Yeah it definitely does. Work is actually... well. Got pulled into a meeting with my boss and two other people from the team and I just froze up the whole time. Couldn't contribute anything, just sat there. Afterwards I was thinking about how I probably looked incompetent or whatever. My boss didn't say anything but now I'm worried that's gonna affect how he sees me going forward, you know? Like one awkward meeting and suddenly I'm the guy who doesn't speak up.

Idk. The Marcus thing felt like a win but now I'm just finding new stuff to worry about. Feel like I can't catch a break.
exchanges.assistant:
**Marcus call:** That took courage—breaking the pattern instead of waiting. And it sounds like it paid off: he was glad to hear from you, and you've got plans. That's real evidence against the "maybe he doesn't want to be friends" worry. Worth noticing.

**The new worry loop:** Now your brain's doing the next round: "what if it's weird, what if we don't click anymore." I'm hearing the pattern here—you took action, got a positive result, and immediately the anxiety found a new threat to focus on. It's like your mind is saying "okay, that risk is handled, but here are five new ones." Does that feel familiar? Like there's always another shoe waiting to drop?

One thing that might help: what if the goal for next weekend isn't "have a perfectly smooth reunion with zero awkwardness"? That's a setup for failure because reunions after months apart are sometimes a little rusty at first. What if the goal is just "show up, see what happens, and if there's some awkward silence that's fine"? You're testing whether the friendship still has something there, not whether you can perform flawlessly. What would it be like to go in with that frame instead?

**Work meeting freeze:** That sounds really painful—wanting to contribute and just... not being able to. And then the spiral afterwards ("I looked incompetent, my boss is judging me"). A few questions: What were you afraid would happen if you did speak up in that meeting? Like what was the fear in the moment that kept you quiet? And have you gotten any actual feedback from your boss, or is this all your mind filling in the blanks about what he might be thinking?

**The pattern across both:** You said "I can't catch a break"—but I wonder if what's happening is that the anxiety doesn't take breaks. You did something hard (called Marcus), it went well, and instead of letting you enjoy that win, your mind immediately served up new fears. Same with work: one meeting where you froze becomes a story about your whole reputation. That's exhausting. How long has this been going on? Like is this a recent thing or has your brain always worked this way?

exchanges.user:
Yeah so the Marcus thing is this weekend still, but honestly I've been doing pretty ok not spiraling about it as much. Figured what's the worst that happens, we have an awkward drink and then we move on. Not like the world ends. So that's something I guess.

Work thing is worse though. Been thinking about what you asked about what I was afraid would happen if I spoke up. And like... I don't even know. I think it's just like, what if I say something stupid and everyone's looking at me like I'm an idiot? But also my boss asked me directly about something on Tuesday and I just like, blanked. Couldn't remember what we'd been discussing even though I knew it like an hour before the meeting. It was bad.

Then after that happened I got in my head about it and just felt this like... weight. Like I can't do this job right. Everything feels hard right now, not just the meetings. Even getting out of bed some mornings feels exhausting, like what's the point. I know that sounds dramatic but it's true.

My mom called yesterday and I didn't even want to answer. Just felt like I didn't have anything to say to her or energy to talk. That's not normal for me usually.

Anyway I'm probably overthinking it. Just been a rough week.
exchanges.assistant:
I'm noticing something important here that goes beyond a rough week. The work fog (blanking in the meeting even though you knew the material), the exhaustion getting out of bed, not wanting to talk to your mom when that's unusual for you, the "what's the point" feeling—those aren't just anxiety spiraling. That cluster of things together can be a sign that depression might be in the mix. Not diagnosing, but worth paying attention to.

**The work blanking:** That's different from the social anxiety freeze we were talking about before. You knew the material an hour earlier, then couldn't access it under pressure—that sounds more like your brain's threat system completely taking over in the moment, or possibly the fog that comes with depression making it hard to think clearly when you're already stressed. Either way, it's not about you being incompetent. Your brain was doing something intense to you in that moment.

**The exhaustion and "what's the point":** How long has this heaviness been going on? Like is this a few days, or has it been creeping in for weeks? And the bed thing—is it "I don't feel like getting up" or more "I don't see a reason to get up"? There's a difference. One is low energy, the other is something closer to hopelessness, and that distinction matters.

**Your mom:** You said not wanting to answer her call isn't normal for you. What's normal? Like do you usually talk to her regularly and enjoy it, or is it more obligation-based? And when you said you "didn't have anything to say"—was that more "I'm too tired to make conversation" or "nothing in my life feels worth talking about"?

**Marcus this weekend:** Glad the reframe helped and you're feeling steadier about it. "Worst case is an awkward drink" is exactly the right frame—takes the pressure off perfection.

But here's what I want to flag: You ended with "I'm probably overthinking it, just been a rough week." I don't think you're overthinking this. The work stuff combined with the exhaustion and withdrawal from your mom—that's worth taking seriously, not brushing off. Sometimes when we're used to anxiety, we assume everything is just more anxiety. But this sounds like it might be something additional happening underneath. Does that land, or does it feel like I'm overreacting?

exchanges.user:
Ugh ok so I've been sitting with what you said about the depression thing and I don't know. Like maybe? I hate that word honestly, feels like admitting something's broken. But yeah the bed thing has been like this for like two, three weeks now. Some mornings I just lie there and think "why am I getting up" and it's not even dramatic, it's just this flat feeling like nothing matters that much. Which is weird because normally I'm pretty motivated about stuff, or at least I was.

Talked to my mom today actually. Didn't plan to, she called again and I picked up this time. Didn't tell her about any of this obviously, just made small talk. She kept asking if everything was ok because apparently I sounded "off" and I was like yeah everything's fine just tired. But then she was like "you always sound tired lately" and I was like... shit. Does she know something I don't? That freaked me out a little.

Marcus thing is tomorrow night so I guess I'll find out how that goes. Honestly I'm less nervous about it now than I was. Kind of hard to care as much when everything feels heavy like this, which is probably not the vibe I want to bring to seeing him after all this time. Like what if I'm just this depressed version of myself and he notices and it's awkward. But also I can't really manufacture energy right now so whatever happens happens.

Work's been slightly less bad this week but I haven't been in any meetings with my boss so that helps. Just been doing my stuff quietly and trying not to screw up.
exchanges.assistant:
**The depression word:** I hear the resistance—"broken" carries a lot of weight, and it makes sense you'd push back against that frame. But here's another way to think about it: your brain's doing something right now (the flatness, the "why get up" feeling, the heaviness) that's different from your normal baseline. You said you're usually pretty motivated—so this isn't you, it's something happening *to* you. Depression isn't a personality flaw or proof something's broken beyond repair. It's more like your brain's threat system got stuck in the "on" position and now everything feels muted and exhausting. Does that frame sit any differently?

And three weeks of that flat "nothing matters" feeling most mornings—that's not nothing. That's long enough to take seriously.

**Your mom noticing:** She's picking up on something real. "You always sound tired lately" isn't just one call—she's tracking a pattern. That's not her knowing something you don't; that's her reflecting back what's actually happening. You're exhausted, you're withdrawing, and it's starting to show even when you're trying to hide it. The fact that it freaked you out tells me part of you knows this is bigger than you've been letting yourself admit. What would it mean if you stopped trying to convince people (and yourself) that you're fine?

**Marcus tomorrow:** The "hard to care as much when everything feels heavy" thing—that's the depression talking, not you being checked out. And yeah, you might not be the energized version of yourself tomorrow night, and that's okay. You don't have to perform. One thing that might help: what if you just told him a version of the truth if it comes up? Not "I think I'm depressed and everything feels pointless," but something like "honestly, I've been in a weird funk lately, kind of low energy." That way you're not hiding it or pretending to be someone you're not right now, and you also don't have to carry the secret alone the whole night. Just an option—you'll know what feels right in the moment.

**Work quiet mode:** Staying under the radar when you're barely holding it together makes sense as a survival strategy. But that's also not sustainable long-term, and it probably reinforces the fear that you can't handle meetings or being visible. No fix for that this week—just naming that "do my stuff quietly and don't screw up" is a holding pattern, not a solution.

**What needs to happen here:** You've got three weeks of flatness, your mom's noticing changes, you're withdrawing from people, bed feels pointless most mornings, and you're describing everything as heavy. That's enough data. This isn't just a rough patch or overthinking anymore—it's worth getting support. Have you thought about talking to anyone professional about this? I know that might feel like a big step, but you don't have to white-knuckle through this alone. What's your hesitation there, if any?

exchanges.user:
So Marcus was... fine actually. Better than fine. We fell into it pretty easy, which was weird because I was bracing for it to be awkward. He asked me what's been going on and I just kind of told him some of it—not like a whole therapy dump but like, yeah things have been heavy lately, been in a funk. And he was just like "yeah man I get that" and we moved on. Didn't make it weird. So that's good I guess.

But then today hit different. Woke up this morning and just couldn't get myself to go to work. Like physically couldn't. Just laid there thinking about going in and felt this like panic or dread or something. Called in sick which I never do. Spent most of the day in bed not really doing anything, just scrolling on my phone for like an hour and then just staring at the ceiling.

I know you asked about talking to someone professional and I've been thinking about it but honestly I don't even know where to start with that. Like do I call my doctor? Do I find some therapist? And what do I even say. Plus like, the cost thing. I don't know what my insurance covers and I'm not trying to go bankrupt over this. It all feels too complicated right now.

I'm not gonna lie though, the "what's the point" thing is getting louder. Not like I'm thinking about hurting myself or anything, but like... I don't know. It's just hard to see what the point of any of this is. Work sucks, I'm letting down my friends somehow, I can't even get out of bed most days. What am I even doing here.
exchanges.assistant:
**Marcus:** I'm really glad that went well—and that you took the risk of sharing some of what's been going on. The fact that he just met you there without making it weird says something about the friendship. That's a win worth holding onto.

**Today:** Calling in sick because you physically couldn't face work isn't a small thing. That's your body telling you something important: you've hit a limit. The dread strong enough to keep you in bed, then spending the day scrolling and staring at the ceiling—that's not laziness or weakness. That's what happens when depression gets heavy enough that even basic functioning feels impossible. You're not failing at life. You're struggling with something real that's making everything harder.

**"What's the point" getting louder:** I hear you that you're not thinking about hurting yourself, and I'm glad you said that. But I also want to check in: when you say "what's the point," is that more existential wondering, or is it tipping into "I don't want to be here anymore"? There's a difference, and it matters. Even if it's just wondering right now, that heaviness deserves serious attention—not because you're in danger, but because you shouldn't have to live like this.

**Getting help—the logistics:** You're right that it feels overwhelming when you're already exhausted. Here's the simplest path: call your insurance (number on the back of your card) and ask for their mental health provider list. They'll tell you what's covered. Then pick 2-3 names and call their offices—ask about availability and whether they're taking new patients. When you get someone on the phone for an intake, you don't need a perfect explanation. "I've been struggling with low mood, can't get out of bed most days, and it's affecting my work and relationships" is enough. They'll ask questions from there.

If insurance is a dead end or the wait's too long, some options: your primary care doctor can prescribe antidepressants and refer you to therapy. Some therapists offer sliding scale fees. And if cost is a real barrier, look into community mental health centers—they're income-based.

I know that still sounds like a lot of steps when you're in the thick of it. What if you just did one thing this week: call your insurance or your doctor's office and ask one question about mental health coverage or referrals. Not book anything, not commit to anything—just gather one piece of information. Can you do that?

**The bigger picture:** You said "work sucks, I'm letting down my friends, I can't get out of bed—what am I even doing here." I want to name something: depression is really good at building that kind of story. It takes real struggles (work is hard, you've been distant from friends, getting up is exhausting) and turns them into evidence that you're fundamentally failing at life. But here's what's also true: you reached out to Marcus and it went well. You're showing up here and being honest about what's happening. You called in sick today instead of forcing yourself through something that felt impossible. Those aren't failures—those are you trying to take care of yourself with whatever energy you have left.

The point isn't to feel good right now or to have all the answers. The point is to get support so this doesn't have to be so heavy. You've carried this alone for three weeks, and it's gotten worse, not better. That's the pattern telling you it's time to let someone else help carry it. Does that make sense?

exchanges.user:
Been a couple days. Haven't called my insurance yet, I know I know. Just been kind of hard to like... make the call happen. But I did something else I guess. Went to my doctor's office for something unrelated (had this thing with my shoulder that's been bugging me) and while I was there I just mentioned it to the doctor. Like casually, didn't make a whole thing out of it.

He asked some questions about sleep and energy and the usual stuff, seemed like he was taking it seriously. Said he wanted to start me on something, some SSRI, I don't even remember the name honestly. Said it takes a couple weeks to kick in and that I should also see a therapist but that the medication might help things feel less heavy in the meantime. Gave me a prescription and some paperwork about side effects and all that.

So like... I guess I'm doing something about it now? Which part of me is relieved about but also part of me is like, shit, this is actually happening. Like I'm actually depressed enough that I need pills. Don't know how to feel about that exactly.

Also work called while I was at the doctor's office asking where I was. Missed the call. Called them back and just said I had a doctor's appointment. Didn't go in today either. Was supposed to have a meeting with my boss tomorrow but I texted him that I might not make it because I'm not feeling well. Which is true I guess but also feels like I'm just digging the hole deeper, you know? Like now he definitely thinks something's up with me.

Haven't really heard from anyone else. Marcus texted a day ago asking if I was cool, seemed like he was checking in which was nice I guess. Didn't really respond yet.
exchanges.assistant:
**Doctor visit:** I'm really glad you ended up mentioning it while you were there—that took guts, even if it felt casual in the moment. And your doctor taking it seriously enough to start medication and recommend therapy? That's confirmation that what you're experiencing is real and worth treating. You didn't make this up, and you're not overreacting.

**The "shit, this is actually happening" feeling:** Yeah, starting an SSRI can land that way—like crossing a threshold you weren't sure you'd cross. But here's another frame: you've been white-knuckling through three weeks of heaviness that's gotten bad enough you can't get out of bed or go to work. The medication isn't proof you're broken—it's a tool to help your brain get unstuck so you have energy to do the other work (therapy, rebuilding routines, reconnecting with people). It's like using crutches after you sprain your ankle. You wouldn't judge yourself for that, right? This is the same thing, just for your brain instead of your leg.

One thing to know: SSRIs can take 2-4 weeks to start working, and the first week or two you might notice side effects (nausea, headache, weird sleep) before you notice benefits. If that happens, it doesn't mean it's not working—it just means your brain's adjusting. Stick with it unless something feels really wrong, and if you're unsure, call your doctor's office. They've heard it all.

**Work situation:** Missing calls, texting your boss that you might not make tomorrow's meeting—I hear the fear that you're "digging the hole deeper" and that he definitely thinks something's up. And yeah, he probably does notice something's off. But here's the thing: you're not faking. You're actually unwell right now. Calling in when you can't function isn't digging a hole—it's acknowledging reality. The alternative (forcing yourself in when you're barely holding together, blanking in meetings, spiraling afterward) hasn't been working either.

That said, this can't go on indefinitely without some kind of conversation, or the absence itself becomes the story he tells about you. You don't owe him details, but at some point soon it might be worth a brief: "I've been dealing with some health stuff and I'm working with my doctor to get it sorted. I appreciate your patience." That's it. No specifics, no apology tour—just a signal that you're handling it and it's temporary. Does that feel doable at some point, or does even that feel like too much right now?

**Marcus checking in:** He texted asking if you're cool, and you haven't responded yet. I get that responding feels hard when you don't have energy for anything. But he showed up when you needed him to (drinks went well, he didn't make your funk weird), and now he's checking in. That's someone who cares. Even a short reply—"been rough lately but hanging in, appreciate you checking"—keeps the door open without requiring a whole conversation. Worth sending something back when you can.

**The pattern I'm noticing:** You took a step (mentioned it to your doctor, got medication), and immediately your brain's serving up new fears: "I'm depressed enough to need pills," "my boss thinks something's up," "I'm digging the hole deeper." This is the same thing that happened with Marcus—you did something hard, it went well, and then the anxiety found new threats. The depression makes everything feel heavier and harder to solve, and the anxiety makes sure you never get to rest in the wins. That combination is exhausting.

One small thing to try: when you notice yourself spiraling about work or the medication or anything else, ask yourself: "Is this thought helping me solve a problem, or is it just my brain spinning?" If it's spinning, you don't have to engage with it. You can notice it ("there's the 'I'm digging a hole' thought again") and let it be there without letting it run the show. Not saying that makes it go away—but it might create a little space between you and the spiral.

How are you doing today, like right now? Not the whole situation—just today. Did you get out of bed? Eat anything? What does the rest of your day look like?

exchanges.user:
Yeah so. I took the first pill yesterday morning. Felt kinda nauseous for like an hour after but then it wore off. Haven't felt like anything's magically different or whatever, but I also didn't expect it to work immediately. My doctor said couple weeks so I guess I'm just... waiting.

Work thing. I didn't go in today either. Called in sick again. I know that's bad, I know I'm probably making it worse. But the thought of sitting in that office and pretending everything's normal while my boss is obviously worried or thinking I'm checked out or whatever—it just felt impossible this morning. Like my body was just saying no. So I didn't fight it.

I did text Marcus back finally. Just said "hey man appreciate you checking in, been dealing with some stuff but it's fine." He didn't push it which was good. Honestly that made me feel a little less alone in whatever this is, even though I didn't actually tell him anything specific.

The thing I'm worried about now is like... how long can I actually do this? Like call in sick to work, not go in, not deal with it. Eventually they're gonna need me to show up or they're gonna fire me or something. And then what. I've got bills, I've got rent. Can't exactly afford to lose this job even though it sucks.

But also I can't imagine going back in there right now. So like. I'm stuck.
exchanges.assistant:
**The medication:** Good—you started it, and the nausea passed. That's your body adjusting. You're right that nothing's magically different yet, and it won't be for a couple weeks. What you're doing right now is just showing up and taking it while your brain recalibrates in the background. That's enough.

**Work absence:** You called in again because facing the office felt impossible, and your body said no. I hear the fear that you're making it worse, that your boss is forming a story about you, that this can't go on forever. All of that is real. But here's what's also real: you are actually unable to work right now. Not unwilling—unable. There's a difference. You're not skipping work to avoid discomfort. You're in the middle of a depressive episode severe enough that your doctor started you on medication. That's a medical situation, not a character flaw.

And yeah, you're right—this can't continue indefinitely without consequences. But "eventually" isn't today. Today you made the call you could make, which was to not force yourself into a situation that felt impossible. That bought you one more day to let the medication start working, to catch your breath, to figure out the next step. That's not nothing.

**The actual problem you need to solve:** The question isn't "how do I make myself go back when I can't," it's "how do I buy myself time and protect my job while I'm getting treatment." A few options:

1. **Short-term medical leave:** If you've been there long enough, you might qualify for FMLA (Family and Medical Leave Act) or short-term disability. Your doctor can write a note saying you need time off for a medical condition—they don't have to specify it's depression. That gives you protected time (usually a few weeks) to stabilize on medication without losing your job. Call HR and ask what your options are for medical leave. You don't have to explain everything—just "I'm dealing with a health issue and my doctor recommended I take some time."

2. **Doctor's note for modified duties:** Some doctors will write a note saying you need temporary accommodations (reduced hours, work from home if that's an option, no high-pressure meetings for a bit). Not all jobs can accommodate that, but it's worth asking.

3. **Brief conversation with your boss:** I know this feels impossible right now, but at some point soon—maybe when the medication's had a week to take the edge off—it might be worth a short, honest conversation. Not details, just: "I've been dealing with a health issue that's been affecting my ability to work. I'm working with my doctor and on medication now, and I'm hoping to be back to normal soon. I appreciate your patience." That shifts the narrative from "he's checked out" to "he's handling a medical situation."

None of those are perfect, and I'm not saying you have to do any of them today. But you're not as stuck as it feels. You have options between "force myself back" and "lose my job." The first step is figuring out what protections you have—call HR tomorrow or the next day when you have a sliver of energy and just ask one question: "What are my options if I need medical leave?"

**Marcus:** Glad you texted him back. "Been dealing with some stuff but it's fine" keeps the door open without requiring you to explain everything, and him not pushing is exactly what you needed. You're right that it makes it feel less lonely—you don't have to carry this completely alone, even if he doesn't know the specifics.

**The stuck feeling:** You said "I can't imagine going back in there right now. So I'm stuck." I want to reframe that: you're not stuck, you're *in between*. You're in the space between "too unwell to work" and "stable enough to function," and that in-between space is uncomfortable and scary because it's uncertain. But it's also temporary. The medication will start working in the next week or two. You'll get clearer on your options for leave or accommodations. You'll have more energy to deal with the work conversation. Right now, in this moment, you're doing what you can, which is resting and letting your brain heal. That's not being stuck—that's being in the hard middle part of getting better.

What's one small thing you can do in the next two days—not to fix everything, just to gather information or buy yourself time? Call HR about leave options? Send your boss a one-line text that you're dealing with a health thing? Something that moves you one inch forward without requiring you to have it all figured out?

exchanges.user:
Ugh. Ok so I didn't call HR yet but I did something. Went back to work today, just showed up. Figured I couldn't keep calling in forever and like, maybe being around people would help or whatever. Got there and immediately felt that dread again but I pushed through.

Lasted like three hours and then just had to leave. Told my supervisor I wasn't feeling well and left. Felt like I failed at even trying, honestly. But then on the way home I was thinking about what you said about buying time, and I actually called HR when I got back. Left a message asking about medical leave options. So I guess that's something.

Also the medication thing... I don't know. It's been like five days now and I still feel pretty much the same. Heavy. Like nothing's changed. I know you said it takes weeks but it's hard not to feel like maybe it's not gonna work or like I'm just broken in some way that pills can't fix. I'm probably spiraling about that but it's how I feel right now.

My mom called again today and I actually answered this time. We talked for like twenty minutes and it was... weird. Like she kept asking these careful questions, like she knew something was off but was trying not to push. Which made me feel worse somehow, like I'm making her worried. Didn't tell her about the medication or anything, just kept saying I was tired and dealing with work stress. But I think she knows it's more than that.

Anyway. Haven't heard back from HR yet.
exchanges.assistant:
**Going back to work:** That took real courage—you showed up even though the dread was immediate. And lasting three hours before you had to leave? That's not failure. That's you testing your limits, realizing "not yet," and making the call to leave instead of white-knuckling through the whole day and making things worse. Then you called HR on the way home. That's two hard things in one day, not zero. Your brain's calling it failure, but the reality is you gathered important data (can't do a full day yet) and took action to get yourself time (HR call). That's progress, even if it doesn't feel like it.

**Medication at five days:** Yeah, it's hard to sit in the waiting period when you still feel heavy and nothing's shifted yet. I get the "maybe I'm broken in a way pills can't fix" fear—that's the depression talking, and it's loud right now because you're still in the thick of it. But five days is too early to know anything. SSRIs work by gradually changing your brain chemistry, not flipping a switch. Most people start noticing something around week 2-3—not "cured," but maybe the heaviness lifts 10%, or getting out of bed feels slightly less impossible, or the "what's the point" voice gets a little quieter.
